title: No worries! Just grin and beer it while in Prague
text: No worries! Just grin and beer it while in Prague By ET Bureau | 9 Jul, 2015, 05.07AM IST ET SPECIAL: Love visual aspect of news? Enjoy this exclusive slideshows treat! By Rashmi Hemrajani Experience unique trails on a holiday as it will throw up interesting and new perspectives to your vacation. Why it is important to go on a culinary trail while on a holiday? Firstly, the trail will be a great insight to know what's produced locally and also a way to meet like-minded tourists. Also a food trail will serve the best dishes that a city has to offer. And who doesn't like to share tales of distinctive encounters back home. Cheese, Olive oil, Barbecue... Cheese: There are approx 150 cheesemakers along Holland fs mushrooming cheese trail, ranging from big companies to small-scale artisan producers. Larger producers offer tours and gift shops for cheesy souvenirs. œ Olive Oil: A handful of farmers in the Napa and Sonoma Valleys north of San Francisco have started to offer olive-oil tastings. If you want to understand the process behind healthy olive oil, then take your family and friends for an unforgettable tour. Barbecue: Yes , all you meat lovers we heard you. Hop on a flight to Texas to bite into the best barbecue dishes. It is said that German and Czech immigrants brought their traditions here, and now this has become one of the biggest tourist attractions. With so much to do (and eat), book on a sumptuous experience and remember to share with us. Spirit trails Region: Czech Republic, France and Japan For Beer lovers, Central and southern Bohemia is what Bordeaux is to the wine connoisseur. Czech Republic is true beer country, where small villages and unsung towns harbour hidden breweries and down-toearth bars. Tourists often spend an afternoon in the heart of Prague's old town at U Fleku brewery, proudly serving their famous dark lager since 1499. The tour guides you through a traditional Czech brewing process with a visit to the copper mashers and a unique open fermenting vat. France is recognised as one of the world's largest wine producers and is home to some of the planet's famous wine districts including: Alsace, Rhone and Provence. From Paris, tourists can easily get to France's northernmost region, Champagne and enjoy the world's most expensive bubbles. Those who prefer red wine or chilled Chardonnay should head to the Burgundy wine districts and the Loire Valley. Whiskey got its start in Japan in 1923 when a man named Shinjiro Torii— inspired by Scotland's traditions and strict quality control — opened his first distillery, Yamazaki, just outside Kyoto. In recent years, Japan's distilleries have won top international awards by the barrelful. Head to Osaka to get a sniff of Japan's whisky flavours.
